start.title:
Underwater Archaeology

Mission: The Black Sea Anomaly
start.description: Deep beneath the Black Sea lies one of Earth's most extraordinary time capsules. Below 200 meters, oxygen-starved waters have preserved wooden shipwrecks for thousands of years. Help Dr. Albert Lin to use polynomial equations to identify these lost shipwrecks — some of history's greatest underwater treasures.

S3_D0_FX_C0.imgDescription: Ancient Greek ships departing from a busy harbor with traders loading cargo, showing the extensive Mediterranean trade network.
S3_D0_FX_C0.imgDescription2: Satellite view showing Greek trading colonies (marked in red) spanning from Spain to Russia around the Mediterranean and Black Sea.
S3_D0_FX_C0.imgDescription3: Historical map displaying Greek settlements around the Black Sea.
S3_D0_FX_C0.imgDescription4: Modern research vessel with satellite dishes, sonar arrays, and ROV cranes positioned over Black Sea waters.
S3_D0_FX_C0.imgDescription5: Ship's command center with glowing monitors displaying colorful seafloor heat maps and bathymetric data.

help.heading: How to use this tool?
help.body:
Adjust the yellow Calibration Line so it matches the green Seafloor Map as closely as possible.

How to Calibrate?

  1. Select the polynomial degree (n): Choose the curve's complexity using the degree buttons (n = 2, n = 3 etc.).
    1. Lower degrees create simpler shapes
    2. Higher degrees allow for more complex curves
  2. Adjust Equation Parameters: Use the dials to fine-tune.
    1. Stretch (a): Controls how steep or flat the curve is
    2. Horizontal Shift (h): Moves the curve left or right
    3. Vertical Shift (k): Moves the curve up or down
  3. Check Your Match: Once the yellow line overlaps the green curve closely, click 'Check Match' to test your calibration.

info.heading: Polynomial Equations and Transformations
info.body:
A polynomial is a mathematical expression made up of terms involving variables raised to whole-number powers. The vertex form of the polynomial is written as:

f(x) = a(x - h)2 + k

In this equation:

  • a controls the stretch of the curve — how steep or wide it is.
  • h adjusts the horizontal position, shifting the curve left or right.
  • k controls the vertical position, moving the curve up or down.

The degree of a polynomial is the highest exponent of the variable. It determines the curve's overall complexity:

  • A degree 1 polynomial is a straight line.
  • A degree 2 polynomial (as shown above) creates a U-shaped curve.
  • Higher-degree polynomials (3, 4, 5, etc.) can bend and turn more, allowing them to model more complex shapes.

By adjusting parameters like a, h, and k, you can transform the polynomial's graph to better fit a pattern or dataset. These transformations help us understand and represent real-world relationships through math.

S3.S3_D1_FX_C0: The ancient Greek civilization was built on trade. Their ships carried goods like wine, olive oil, and furs—and also precious cargo like gold, silver and beautiful pottery.
S3.S3_D2_FX_C0: By 600 BCE, Greek colonies had spread across the Mediterranean and Black Sea, from modern Spain to Russia—all connected by trade.
S3.S3_D3_FX_C0: Ancient Greek shipwrecks have been found in the deepest waters of the Black Sea. In this unique “anoxic zone,” the lack of oxygen prevents rot and decay. This means that shipwrecks can be frozen in time for thousands of years.
S3.S3_D4_FX_C0: Today, Dr. Albert Lin and his team are using cutting-edge sensors to locate ancient Greek shipwrecks in the anoxic zone of the Black Sea. Today's mission: map the sea floor, search for shipwrecks and discover what precious cargo still lies in its hold.
S3.S3_D4_FX_C3: How are we going to find a shipwreck in all this water?
S3.S3_D5_FX_C1: The Black Sea is enormous. But here's the plan: We are going to use sensor data to create a simplified model of the seafloor. Then we will look for anomalies — bumps in the data that don't fit the pattern.
S3.S3_D6_FX_C2: Ok, here's our first challenge: we've got satellite bathymetry data, which gives us a pretty solid map of the seafloor. But now we need to calibrate our systems so we can navigate underwater.
S3.S3_D8_FX_C2: The GPS signals don't penetrate seawater. Help me calibrate these maps, so the submersible can navigate safely underwater.
S3.S3_D1_FX_C1: Look at this — the ends are pointing opposite directions—one up, one down. That tells us the polynomial degree is odd.
S3.S3_D3_FX_C1: I mean, odd or even. Even degree polynomials have both ends facing the same direction. See the difference with odd degrees? Compare x² or x⁴—an even degree—with odd degrees, like x³ or x⁵.
S3.S3_D4_FX_C1: Which degree do you think will model this trench better: cubic or quartic?
S3.S3_D5_FX_C3: So, what do the degrees actually do?
S3.S3_D6_FX_C1: They control curve complexity. Degree 1 is a line. Degree 2 curves once. Higher degrees can have more curves and can model more complex shapes.
S3.S3_D7_FX_C2: Actually, this polynomial looks different than I expected. Don't they usually have every term like x³ + x² + x + constant?
S3.S3_D8_FX_C1: This is the vertex form of the polynomial—it makes position control easier. That stretch (a) factor is your leading coefficient. Watch how the curve steepens or flattens as you adjust it.
S3.S3_D9_FX_C1: Take a look at the parameters h and k — these control how the calibration line moves on the map. Adjusting h will shift the curve horizontally, while k moves it vertically. Try adjusting the dials to find a match. To calibrate the system, click 'Check Match'.
S3.S3_D10_FX_C1: Excellent work! The calibration model perfectly matches the seafloor data. Your system is now operational.
S3.S3_D9_FX_C2: This is still a polynomial equation, right?

S4.S4_D1_FX_C2: Satellites can map the seafloor at a coarse resolution. But we will need more detail to find a shipwreck.
S4.S4_D2_FX_C1: It looks like our laser scans of the seafloor are nearly complete.
S4.S4_D3_FX_C2: Laser scans will produce a lot of data. How do you plan to process it all?
S4.S4_D4_FX_C1: We'll simplify the data by modeling it with polynomial equations.
S4.S4_D6_FX_C1: It's not hard. The computer uses regression algorithms to fit polynomial curves to the data points collected from the lasers.

S5_D0_FX_C9.title: Polynomial Model of Sea Floor Laser Scans

translations.missionBriefingText: Analyze the provided telemetry data. The scan indicates a steep trench wall adjacent to a relatively flat ledge. A significant anomaly (potential shipwreck) has been detected on this ledge. Use the controls to fit a polynomial model to the data points to quantify the anomaly.

help.heading: How to find a polynomial that accurately represents the anomaly?
help.body:
• Click the 'Slice Data' button to extract a cross-sectional curve from the seafloor scan that highlights the anomaly.
  • Click the 'Model Data' button to fit a polynomial regression model to the sliced data.
  • Use the model degree slider to adjust the degree of the polynomial and observe the corresponding R2 value, which indicates the goodness of fit.
  • Identify and select the lowest-degree polynomial that achieves a high R2 value (typically close to or above 0.9), ensuring the model accurately fits the anomaly without overfitting.

info.heading: Model fitting and R² in Polynomial Regression
info.body:
Polynomial regression is a way to model data by fitting a smooth curve to a set of points. The curve is defined by a polynomial equation, and the degree of the polynomial controls how simple or complex the curve is. A low-degree polynomial gives a simple, smooth shape, while a higher-degree polynomial can follow more detailed patterns in the data.

Model fitting means finding the best polynomial curve that matches the data as closely as possible. To measure how well the curve fits, we use R2 (R-squared). R2 is a number between 0 and 1 that shows how closely the model matches the data points. An R2 close to 1 means the model fits the data very well.

S5.S5_D1_FX_C2: Here we go: a 3D map of the sea floor— and look at that anomaly! Let's take a slice so we can model it.
S5.S5_D2_FX_C1: The seafloor is relatively smooth. That means a lower degree polynomial can easily model it—but it will miss fine details.
S5.S5_D3_FX_C2: Ok. But a small wreck on the smooth seafloor will require a much higher-degree polynomial to detect.
S5.S5_D4_FX_C3: Wait, so higher degree polynomials are needed to model more complex shapes?
S5.S5_D5_FX_C1: That's right. Lower degree polynomials can show the general shape of the seafloor, but will miss fine details.
S5.S5_D6_FX_C2: Let’s play around with the model degrees and fit some different models. Try adjusting the model <no-glossary>degree</no-glossary> slider and click on the "Fit Model" button.
S5.S5_D7_FX_C1: Note the R² — that shows the “goodness of fit” of the polynomial regression. It shows how well the polynomial line matches the scanning data.
S5.S5_D8_FX_C2: At minimum, what degree polynomial do we need so our model R² is over 0.9?
S5.S5_D9_FX_C2: Great work, team! This suggests the anomaly is definitely worth checking out.
S5.S5_D10_FX_C3: So, what do you think that bump is? Treasure??
S5.S5_D11_FX_C1: It could be a shipwreck — or just some sensor noise. We'll need to verify it with multiple sensor sweeps.
S5.S5_D12_FX_C2: Deploy the drone boats! We're going to need multiple data sources to confirm this anomaly.

S6.S6_D1_FX_C1: Each of our drone boats is carrying a different sensor package for generating different polynomial models of the seafloor.
S6.S6_D2_FX_C3: How will you merge all that data?
S6.S6_D3_FX_C1: First, we will add the polynomials from the first two scans. Then, we will subtract the polynomial representing the background seafloor variation.

S9_D0_FX_C9.title: Merging Sensor Data

chips.scanA: Drag Scan A: x square plus 2x. Press enter or click to place this item in the operations console.
chips.scanB: Drag Scan B: minus 3 x square plus x minus 3. Press enter or click to place this item in the operations console.
chips.scanC: Drag Scan C: 4 x plus 1. Press enter or click to place this item in the operations console.

S9_D0_FX_C9.graph: Graph showing the noise curve and results of combined sonar scans.

help.heading: How to use this tool?
help.body:
• Drag and drop the scans as per the instructions given.
  • Calculate the result and enter the coefficients in input boxes.

info.heading: How to Add and Subtract Polynomials?
info.body:
Polynomials are expressions made up of terms like 2x2, 3x, or constants like 5. To add or subtract polynomials, you combine like terms, terms that have the same degree.

Let's work with these two polynomials: 2x2 + 3x + 5 and x2 + 4x + 2

Addition Example:

(2x2 + 3x + 5) + (x2 + 4x + 2)

Group like terms: (2x2 + x2) + (3x + 4x) + (5 + 2)

Add: 3x2 + 7x + 7

Subtraction Example:

(2x2 + 3x + 5) - (x2 + 4x + 2)

Distribute the negative sign: 2x2 + 3x + 5 - x2 - 4x - 2

Group like terms: (2x2 - x2) + (3x - 4x) + (5 - 2)

Subtract: x2 - x + 3

The key is to combine terms with the same degree by adding or subtracting their coefficients.

S9.S9_D1_FX_C1: Scan A plus Scan B gives us the combined sensor data. Drag and drop the Scan A and Scan B data chips into the empty boxes inside the Operations Console to begin the calculation.
S9.S9_D2_FX_C1: Now let's add Scan A and Scan B. When adding polynomials, what do we add together?
S9.S9_D3_FX_C3: Like, x2 + x2 = 2x2?
S9.S9_D4_FX_C2: Exactly. Like terms combine, unlike terms— like x and x2 stay separate.
S9.S9_D5_FX_C2: x2 and x3 are like terms that can be combined.
S9.S9_D6_FX_C1: Good. Now enter the correct coefficients for each term in the Result 1 to complete the addition of Scan A and Scan B.
S9.S9_D7_FX_C1: Now, let's subtract the background seafloor scan to isolate the anomaly. Drag and drop the Scan C data chip into the empty box inside the Operations Console to begin the calculation.
S9.S9_D8_FX_C1: Subtract Scan C from Result 1 and enter the correct coefficients for each term in the Result 2.
S9.S9_D9_FX_C3: Super! This confirms it. We are definitely picking up something big down there—it's just the right size for a shipwreck!
S9.S9_D10_FX_C2: Now it's time for visual <no-glossary>proof</no-glossary>. Deploy the submersibles!

S10_D0_FX_C0.imgDescription: Advanced deep-sea ROV Poseidon descending through the azure water column, its bright LED lights piercing the darkness as it approaches the archaeological site thousands of feet below the surface.
S10_D0_FX_C0.imgDescription2: ROV camera reveals a stunning ancient Greek merchant vessel resting on the ocean floor, with its curved hull and distinctive bow perfectly preserved in the deep sea darkness, illuminated by the submersible's powerful lights.
S10_D0_FX_C0.imgDescription3: Close-up view of a weathered wooden cargo chest sitting on the sandy ocean floor, its ancient bronze fittings and iron clasps still intact after centuries underwater, surrounded by the mysterious deep-sea environment.

S10.S10_D1_FX_C1: Our remotely operated submersibles are descending to target coordinates.
S10.S10_D2_FX_C3: This is it! We're about to see actual ancient treasure!
S10.S10_D3_FX_C2: Leo, we're archaeologists. This is about preserving cultural history.
S10.S10_D4_FX_C3: Of course, of course. But I've got a good feeling about this!
S10.S10_D5_FX_C1: Cameras are online... Ok, Albert, you need to see this.
S10.S10_D6_FX_C2: That ship is at least 2000 years old—but it looks like it went down last week!
S10.S10_D7_FX_C3: No way. The mast of the ship is still standing. I can even see rigging!
S10.S10_D8_FX_C1: Look at those amphora jars. Perfect condition! And… I think I see something gleaming in the sediment!
S10.S10_D9_FX_C3: GOLD! I told you we'd find pirate treasure!
S10.S10_D10_FX_C2: Not pirates, Leo. Greek merchants. But you might not be wrong about the treasure.
S10.S10_D11_FX_C1: I do see something shining down there...
S10.S10_D12_FX_C2: And do you see that wooden container? Just imagine what's inside. In this anoxic zone, even ancient scrolls might be preserved!
S10.S10_D14_FX_C1: This is just the beginning. The mathematical models suggest there are many more ships down here.
S10.S10_D15_FX_C2: We may be on the threshold of a major new era in understanding our ancient past.

quest_completion.subheading: You Have Explored Polynomials in Archaeological Discovery!
quest_completion.content:
You successfully completed the Black Sea Shipwreck STEAMQuest.

  • You learned how polynomial degrees control curve complexity
  • You used polynomial regression to model seafloor terrain
  • You merged multiple data sources using polynomial addition and subtraction

Your mathematical skills have uncovered a priceless piece of human history!
quest_completion.leftsvgarialabel: ship with crown icon on yellow shield badge

regression.definition: Regression is a method used to find a curve or line that best fits a set of data points.

bathymetry.definition: The study and mapping of the seafloor's depth and shape is known as bathymetry.

anoxic_zone.definition: An anoxic zone is a part of the ocean with little or no oxygen, where decay happens very slowly.

submersible.definition: A submersible is a small underwater vehicle that can dive deep to explore the ocean.

anomaly.definition: An anomaly is a spot on the seafloor that looks different from the surrounding area and may indicate something unusual, like a shipwreck or underwater structure.

anomalies.definition: Anomalies (anomaly) is a spot on the seafloor that looks different from the surrounding area and may indicate something unusual, like a shipwreck or underwater structure.

rov.definition: ROV stands for Remotely Operated Vehicle. It is used to investigate shipwrecks without sending humans underwater.

research_vessel.definition: A research vessel is a special ship equipped with scientific tools used to explore and study the ocean.

degree.definition: The highest exponent (power) of the variable in a polynomial is called degree.

drone_boats.definition: Drone boats are uncrewed surface boats equipped with sensors and cameras, used to explore and collect data from the ocean.

mast.definition: A mast is a tall, vertical pole on a ship that supports the sails and rigging.

rigging.definition: The rigging is the system of ropes, cables, and chains used to support and control a ship’s sails and mast.

common.luke_description: A Caucasian male wearing a navy winter coat with a red knit beanie, blue scarf, and holding a tablet while dressed in professional winter attire.
common.albert_description: An Asian male with a warm smile wearing a navy zip-up jacket over a brown scarf, holding a tablet and dressed in casual professional clothing.
common.leo_description: A Latino male with dark hair wearing a navy utility-style jacket over a blue shirt, holding a tablet and presenting a friendly demeanor.
common.bg1_description: Research vessel 'Infinity' sails on calm ocean waters under a vivid orange and blue sunset sky.
common.bg2_description: Vibrant sunset over calm ocean waters with dark clouds glowing orange and blue above horizon.
common.bg3_description: Four yellow autonomous ocean drones float on calm blue water under a bright evening sky.
common.bg4_description: Two crew members monitor sonar and mapping data in a dimly lit ship control room.
common.bg5_description: Single crew member analyzes sonar scan data on multiple glowing digital displays inside a dark ship control room.
common.bg6_description: Deep-sea submersible with glowing headlights descends through dark blue ocean, trailing bubbles toward surface.
common.bg7_description: Underwater archaeological site with ancient shipwreck and amphorae illuminated by submersible lights in deep ocean.
common.bg8_description: Underwater treasure chest beside ancient shipwreck, illuminated by blue light filtering through ocean water.
common.bg9_description: Ship's control room with excited crew celebrating shipwreck match confirmation on sonar display under moonlight.
